results.title: The Boys who came home: recollections of Gallipoli
results.creator_credit: Paul Montgomery, Harvey Broadbent and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This documentary features interviews with veterans of the Gallipoli campaign. Through recollections, photographs and archival film, the history of Australia’s involvement in World war I is explored. The video includes interviews with Turkish veterans of the battle who offer their own stories of tragic loss. The documentary concludes by following a group of Australian veterans who return to the Turkish coast to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli campaign. The video includes footage of the official Dawn Service at Gallipoli on the 75th Anniversary of the dawn landing attended by Prime Minister Hawke.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Montgomery, Harvey Broadbent and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: The Boys
results.creator_credit: Rowan Woods, John Maynard, Robert Connolly, SBS Independant, Premium Movie Partnership, Australian Film Commission and Arenafilm
results.brief_description: Adapted from Gordon Graham’s award-winning 1991 play by Stephen Sewell, which was inspired by the horrific Anita Cobby murder case, ‘The Boys’ is an amazing directorial debut from Rowan Woods. The film follows the events that occur after Brett Sprague (David Wenham), is released from prison after serving time for assaulting the manager of a local bottle shop. Brett’s presence creates a constant sense of tension as everybody in the house - his mother Sandra (Lynette Curran), his two brothers Glenn (John Polson) and Steve (Anthony Hayes), his girlfriend Michelle (a fantastic performance from Toni Collete), Glenn’s wife Jackie (Jeanette Cronin), Steve’s pregnant girlfriend Nola (Anna Lise) and Sandra’s boyfriend George (Pete Smith) - treads carefully around Brett’s restrained anger. The film ocassionally flashes forward to the arrest and trial of the three brothers, building up the suspense as we wait for Brett to explode into violence. The actual murder is never shown but the suspense of the film and the atmosphere created by a superb cast makes this a chilling experience. The film won 4 awards at the 1998 AFI Awards - Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source”. Cinematography by Tristan Milani.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Rowan Woods, John Maynard, Robert Connolly, SBS Independant, Premium Movie Partnership, Australian Film Commission and Arenafilm
results.description:
Adapted from Gordon Graham’s award-winning 1991 play by Stephen Sewell, which was inspired by the horrific Anita Cobby murder case, The Boys is an amazing directorial debut from Rowan Woods.

The film follows the events that occur after Brett Sprague (David Wenham), is released from prison after serving time for assaulting the manager of a local bottle shop. Brett’s presence creates a constant sense of tension as everybody in the house – his mother Sandra (Lynette Curran), his two brothers Glenn (John Polson) and Steve (Anthony Hayes), his girlfriend Michelle (a fantastic performance from Toni Collete), Glenn’s wife Jackie (Jeanette Cronin), Steve’s pregnant girlfriend Nola (Anna Lise) and Sandra’s boyfriend George (Pete Smith) – treads carefully around Brett’s restrained anger. The film occasionally flashes forward to the arrest and trial of the three brothers, building up the suspense as we wait for Brett to explode into violence.

The actual murder is never shown but the suspense of the film and the atmosphere created by a superb cast makes this a chilling experience. The film won four awards at the 1998 AFI Awards – Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source.

Cinematography by Tristan Milani.

The film occasionally flashes forward to the arrest and trial of the three brothers, building up the suspense as we wait for Brett to explode into violence.

The actual murder is never shown but the suspense of the film and the atmosphere created by a superb cast makes this a chilling experience. The film won four awards at the 1998 AFI Awards – Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source.

Cinematography by Tristan Milani.

results.title: The Things you do for a beer
results.creator_credit: Steve Whelan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When World War II broke out, some men would do anything to sign up and when the war was over, most men would do anything for a beer. Steve Whelan came from a family of servicemen and was eager to do his bit. He tells the story of how he and a group of fellow prisoners of war found a way to escape and find a beer.

results.title: Fishing on the Diamantina
results.creator_credit: Wayne Gwynne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Wayne Gwynne joined the Navy in 1960 when he was 17. Spending 5 years at sea, during peacetime, Gwynne got to see things that no one has seen before. While he still can’t talk about those things, he loved his time at sea, especially on his favourite ship, the ‘Diamantina’.

results.title: The Buildings already begun
results.creator_credit: Bill Pettigrew, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Not everyone agreed that the buildings already begun were worth finishing, but, in spite of opposition, Canada built its imposing Houses of Parliament in Ottawa on the hill above the river. From a rich archive of pictures of the federal Parliament buildings as they developed over the past hundred years, this film creates a vivid sense of being there.

results.title: The Building of Boulder Dam
results.creator_credit: Hobart Brownell, Pat Dowling, International Harvester and Dowling and Brownell
results.brief_description: Shows details of the building of the great structure that dammed the Colorado River forming an extensive lake. Varied activities, incidental to the building of the dam are woven into the story of the film.

results.title: A Look from their side
results.creator_credit: Robert Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Reflecting on his service in Borneo during World War II, Robert Cole was impressed by the kindness and warmth of the local people, despite being forced to live through war and poverty. In doing so, they taught Cole about gratitude.

results.title: The Bugs Bunny Road-runner movie
results.creator_credit: Chuck Jones and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A feature length animated film starring everyone’s favourite rabbit, Bugs Bunny. Living in retirement in his carrot-filled mansion in Beverly Hills, Bugs takes us into his portrait gallery where we are introduced to many famous characters such as Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, Elmer Fudd, Pepe le Pew, Wile E. Coyote and Road-runner, and also some of the important people behind the animation scene including Mel Blanc and Tex Avery. The film is interspersed with excerpts from some of the most classic Chuck Jones cartoons including Duck Dodgers, Robin Hood Daffy, Duck Amuck, What’s Opera Doc? with Bugs as our host throughout the fun-filled chaotic adventures. The final twenty minutes of the film consists of a compilation of Road-runner cartoons edited down into one long manic cartoon chase, featuring of course, that old die-hard Wile E. Coyote and the ever elusive Road-runner. Character voices by Mel Blanc and Arthur Q. Bryan.

results.title: The Builders
results.brief_description: A story without words of the construction of a building in Los Angeles, from the first truck taking excavated earth from the site to the last worker waxing the new floors.

results.title: Sink or swim
results.creator_credit: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Gwynneth Cole joined the army in 1944, roles for women were limited. While Cole didn’t get to serve on the front line, she was posted to different bases in Australia as a nurse and faced many hardships and the realities of war. Cole greatly values her time in the army and reflects on the opportunities for women and the independent streak she has passed on to her four daughters.
